meaning_mnemonic: In prison, your mouth is not allowed to talk freely. Get a piece of paper to use in place of your mouth and start writing your thoughts out in <radical>paragraph</radical> form!
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>past</radical>.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>walk</radical>.

You see a narwhal struggling with a measuring tape, trying to measure his <radical>height</radical>! His fins can't reach the end of the tape, but of course he wants to include his glorious tusk. Measuring height is not an easy tusk… er, task for a narwhal, but he'll figure it out. Probably.
When a mama watches over a man, it gives him the <radical>courage</radical> he needs to take on any foe.

Don't confuse this with triceratops. <radical>Grass</radical> is closer together, and a little bushier, like this. It's also more random and squished down in parts. If you see a bush of lines like this, it's probably going to be grass.
A creeper in a rice paddy? That's just a <radical>scarecrow</radical>!

What's under the lid on your cook pot? Legs and fins. <radical>Again</radical>. All you know how to cook is legs (of chicken) and fins, so you cook them again and again and again. You'll be having them for dinner tonight, and again tomorrow, and again the next day. Legs and fins, again and again and again, for the rest of your days.

Alternatively, you can also think of this as a laundry hanger with a pair of pants and two little socks flapping like fins. Because laundry is something you have to do again and again… whether you like it or not!

This is the <radical>broom</radical> radical, because the top part looks like a sideways hand broom and the bottom part looks like a dustpan.

Alternatively, you can remember this one with its components: Wolverine wipes his forehead with a towel every time he picks up a broom, because sweeping gets him sweaty fast. Poor guy can fight supervillains all day, but give him a broom and he's instantly exhausted.
